results.title: Steel (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People and Work”.
Looks at the effect that modernisation of the work processes has had on the industrial relations and the experience of work and its consequences for the traditional skills of steel making. Shot entirely at the BSC Anchor Plant at Scunthorpe, the largest and most up-to-date steel works in Europe, it concentrates on the steel workers themselves. A case study for the students of the sociology of work.

results.title: Steel 'n' skin
results.creator_credit: Steve Shaw and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: The music and dance group Steel ‘n’ Skin represents a fusion of African and Caribbean cultures. Its director, Peter Blackman, explains the group’s real emphasis is on encouraging harmonious race relations. The group is shown on a ten-day tour of Merseyside (Liverpool) performing and encouraging community involvement in dance, African and Caribbean instrument making, Afro-Caribbean Cooking and making African clothes and prints.

results.title: Steel
results.brief_description: A picture of the British steel industry showing all stages in the manufacture of steel from the mining of iron ore to the finished products ranging from small precision instruments to vast keels for ocean-going vessels.

results.title: Staying number one: The Swingers
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, John Cruthers and Musical Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Pop Movie”.
Follows the quest for fame and fortune by the New Zealand rock group, “The Swingers”, in Australia starting with their hit ‘Counting the Beat’ and tracing them through their involvement with the feature film ‘Starstruck’, to their eventual break-up in mid 1982. Includes interviews with promoter Michael Gudinski, the group’s manager, and “The Swingers” themselves as well as several promotion clips.

results.title: Statistics and probabilty. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Robert Clamp, Edward Goldwyn, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Begins with a consideration of the concept of mathematical probability related to the external world by associating probabilities of sample points with relative frequency with which outcomes occur. D.V. Lindley, University College, London, speaks about subjective probability.

results.title: Stations of the elevated
results.brief_description: Beginning in the switching yards as they set out on their daily route, Kirchheimer has photographed New Yorks trains as works of art and canvases for the city’s graffiti. As they travel through the decaying urban landscape, they are juxtaposed with advertisements which the filmmaker calls ‘sanctioned vandalism’. Eloquently combines glimpses of faces, billboards and 20th Century artefacts with an urban jazz soundtrack, by Charles Mingus, to create a political film exploring the possibilities of cinema and the visual texture of urban life.
